script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I’m so excited to dive into this week’s study of Moses 1 and Abraham 3. These chapters really set the stage for understanding who we are and why we’re here. What stands out to you as we start?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Oh, Sarah, there’s so much! I think the biggest thing is how these scriptures answer those fundamental questions about our identity and God’s purpose. Right from the beginning in Moses 1, we see God telling Moses, 'Thou art my son' in verse 4. It’s such a powerful reminder that we’re children of God, and that shapes everything.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that. It’s like God is making sure Moses knows who he is before anything else. How do you think that contrasts with what Satan tries to do in the same chapter?

script.speaker: David
script.text: That’s a great point. In Moses 1:12, Satan comes in and says, 'Moses, son of man, worship me.' It’s the exact opposite of God’s message. Satan wants to tear down our true identity and make us forget we’re children of a Heavenly Father.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly! It’s such a clear difference. I also noticed how Moses stands firm against Satan in verses 13 to 18. What can we learn from how he resists those temptations?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Well, Moses does a few key things. In verse 13, he declares, 'Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.' He holds onto his identity. Then he keeps calling on God’s strength, and by verse 18, he commands Satan to depart in the name of the Only Begotten. It shows us the power of remembering who we are and relying on the Lord.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s beautiful. I think it’s so helpful to see that even after a powerful spiritual experience, temptation still comes. How can we use Moses’s example in our own lives?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I think it starts with holding onto the truth of who we are, just like Moses did. When we’re tempted to doubt ourselves or make choices that pull us away from God, we can remember we’re His children. And like Moses, we can pray and ask for strength. It’s a daily choice to turn to Him.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So true. Let’s shift a bit to Abraham 3, where we learn about our premortal life. Verses 22 to 28 talk about how we existed as spirits before the world was. What do you find meaningful in those verses?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love how Abraham 3:22 describes the spirits as 'the intelligences that were organized before the world was.' It shows we weren’t just created out of nothing—we have an eternal nature. And in verse 25, the Lord says He sent us here to 'prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.' It gives purpose to our choices on earth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s such a powerful perspective. Knowing we lived before this life makes me think about how our decisions now connect to something bigger. How does that truth help us in everyday situations?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It really can ground us. When we face challenges or tough choices, remembering that we’re here to be proven, as Abraham 3:25 says, can help us focus on what matters. It’s not just about the moment—it’s about becoming who God knows we can be. I think it encourages us to choose His way, even when it’s hard.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that connection. It ties back to God’s purpose for us, which we also see in Moses 1:39, where the Lord says, 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' How does that shape the way we see our relationship with Him?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It’s everything, Sarah. That verse shows that God’s whole focus is on helping us return to Him and have eternal life. It’s not just about rules or commandments—it’s about His love for us. Knowing that makes me want to trust Him more and follow His plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so comforting. As we wrap up, what’s one thing you hope listeners will take away from Moses 1 and Abraham 3 this week?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I hope they’ll really feel the truth that they are children of God with a divine purpose. These chapters remind us we’re not here by accident—we’re part of His plan. That identity can give us strength to face anything.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a wonderful thought. I’d like to invite everyone to take a moment this week to read Moses 1:4 and Abraham 3:22-25, and just reflect on what it means to be a child of God. Thanks so much for joining us, David, and thank you all for listening. We’ll see you next time!
